WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Court spent 90 minutes Wednesday debating the meaning of the word "appropriate." What it decides could determine whether a clean air regulation 25 years in the making goes into effect next month or back to the drawing board.

The case involves potentially major health and environmental benefits from the reduction of mercury and other airborne toxins — as well as potentially huge costs for power plants and, ultimately, consumers.
But while the Environmental Protection Agency considered the pollution problem and the potential benefits when finalizing its sweeping regulation in 2012, it did not consider costs. Therein, the rub.

In 1990, Congress ordered the EPA to regulate coal- and oil-fired plants if the agency considered it "appropriate and necessary." Opponents of the regulation say "appropriate" must include a consideration of costs.

Twenty states led by Michigan, along with utility companies and the nation's coal mining association, challenged the decision to regulate mercury, arsenic and other pollutants without costs estimates. Their beef was echoed Wednesday by the court's conservative justices.

"I would think it's classic arbitrary and capricious agency action for an agency to command something that is outrageously expensive and ­­in which the expense vastly exceeds whatever public benefit can be achieved," Justice Antonin Scalia said.

But while the estimated annual cost of $9.6 billion is not widely disputed, the cost-benefit ratio is. Opponents say the benefits are as low as $4 million a year. Proponents say when all pollutants are considered, they're as high as $90 billion.

The government says the regulations will prevent premature deaths and illnesses from asthma, cancer and heart disease, as well protecting pregnant women and their unborn children whose fetal brain development can be harmed by overexposure to mercury. Environmental groups say 4,200 to 11,000 lives can be saved each year.

Among the losers would be coal plants, many of which are clustered in the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic states, that have not improved their technology to reduce toxic emissions. Some would be forced to close, which would reduce generating capacity and raise the cost of electricity.

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit upheld the mercury regulations in a 2-1 ruling in December 2013. The majority said the EPA acted reasonably when it declared the emissions hazardous and capable of being controlled. Consideration of costs, it said, could be delayed until specific standards for cutting pollution were set.

During Wednesday's oral argument, the court's liberal justices argued that opponents were trying to force the agency's hand before it can make sense of the cost estimates. Only later, when specific standards for pollution reduction are set, can the EPA do that, they said.
"The word 'appropriate,' I think, is commonly used to indicate that the expert agency will do what it finds fit, based on its expertise," Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said.

But Justice Anthony Kennedy, whose vote could turn out to be pivotal, said under that standard the government could justify regulation just by pointing to the emissions. "'Appropriate,'" he said, "is a capacious term."

Russian President Vladimir Putin, whose recent canceled engagements and disappearance from public view spawned rumors of health problems or worse, appeared in official photos of a meeting purportedly held on Friday.

The three photos, released by the Kremlin, show the Russian president meeting and shaking hands with the head of the Russian Supreme Court. Russia 24, the state broadcaster, also aired video footage of the meeting.

As a sign that Soviet-era Kremlinology — reading political tea leaves — might be back in vogue, CNN, The Guardian and other Western news outlets noted they could not independently confirm such a meeting took place Friday.
Putin's absence was noted after a recent planned meeting in the Kazakh capital, Astana, with the leaders of Kazakhstan and Belarus was postponed on short notice.
Even before Friday's photos surfaced, Putin's spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, was taking pains to quash any rumors of a presidential illness, political or otherwise.

"When the sun comes up in spring, and as soon as spring is in the air, then the fever begins," Peskov told reporters on Thursday, according to the official Tass news agency. "Someone dreams of (Rosneft CEO Igor) Sechin resignation, others — of government resignation, while others have not seen President Putin on TV for several days.
"We are calm on this fever, and respond to the questions with patience," he said.
Peskov told Russian radio station Echo of Moscow that people should not worry, that Putin — known for his manly, shirtless, outdoorsy persona — was "absolutely" healthy.
Asked if the president's handshake was firm, Peskov replied that Putin, a karate black belt, "can break a hand."
Political jitters are perhaps understandable given the intense spotlight on the president following his quarterbacking Russia's military excursions into Ukraine.
Tensions have also been heightened by the recent fatal shooting of outspoken Putin critic Boris Nemtsov only a few-hundred yards from the Kremlin walls.
On Friday, Peskov also dismissed a rumor in some European media that Putin recently became a father.

"The information on a baby born to Vladimir Putin is false," Peskov told Forbes magazine, Tass reported, adding, "I am going to ask people who have money to organize a contest on the best media rumor."
An Israeli journalist has filmed the anti-Semitic experiences he said he had to endure during a 10-hour walk around Paris.
Titled Ten hours walking in Paris as a Jew, the video sees Zvika Klein donning a kippah, or yarmulke, in front of the Eiffel Tower before wandering around the French capital.

While his reception in tourist areas appear peaceful, it is in suburban areas with high Muslim populations where he claims to have received "hateful stares, belligerent remarks, and hostile body language."
In one filmed sequence, a group of suburban youths can be heard saying: "A------. He's gonna get f----- from the front and back."
Walking past a school in one of Paris' neighborhoods, a boy can be heard saying: "Vive Palestine." Others appear to spit as he walks past.

The video was produced for NRG, an Israeli news website owned by Sheldon Adelson, a U.S.-based billionaire who is a friend and supporter of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. It comes amid government concerns of an exodus by France's Jewish citizens in the wake of increasing fears of anti-Semitism.
Some 7,000 French Jews left the country for Israel in 2014, more than double the number of a year before.

That trend had dismayed the French government well before last month's attack on a kosher supermarket in Paris by gunman Amedy Coulibaly, which left four French Jews dead. That latest attack has caused many to question whether they remain safe in the country.
Netanyahu appeared to irk French authorities on Monday by urging Jews in France and Europe to emigrate, saying: "Israel is waiting for you with open arms."
Manuel Valls, the French prime minister, dismissed Netanyahu's comments as electoral-ism ahead of a vote on March 17, adding: "The place for French Jews is France."
This story originally appeared in The Independent. The content was created separately from USA TODAY.
MORE FROM THE INDEPENDENT:
MOORESTOWN, N.J. — Remember that "unprecedented accord'' with the state's largest teachers' union Gov. Chris Christie spoke of earlier this week?
Apparently it's not what he said.
Christie at a town hall Wednesday backed away from his characterization 24 hours earlier of a potential deal with the New Jersey Education Association on a pension system overhaul.
Christie said it's not his fault if people got the impression the NJEA had caved and agreed to givebacks.
He blamed the media for butchering his message, though NJEA leaders who attended the speech Tuesday blasted the Republican governor for jumping the gun, saying there are negotiations but no deal.
"I did not announce we agreed to fix every problem," Christie said at the Moorestown Recreation Center in his 128th town hall, the first one he's hosted since August. "I said we agreed to a roadmap."
NJEA President Wendell Steinhauer after Christie's budget speech Tuesday said the union was "deeply disappointed that Gov. Christie overstated the nature of the understanding."
Steinhauer said negotiations will continue.
Still, Christie at the town hall insisted that "this has been reported a little bit carelessly."

Christie set up a retirement benefits study commission in August. The panel released recommendations Tuesday to cut benefits and to fund a new hybrid defined-benefit, defined-contribution plan, where oversight would belong to unions.
As part of a series of tradeoffs, the panel wants a constitutional amendment to guarantee public employees adequate pension contributions from the state.
"Let's start off this conversation by understanding one thing. To pay for this problem, I'm not raising taxes," Christie said. "It'd be irresponsible to do it."

Later Wednesday, Christie appeared on his monthly Ask the Governor show on 101.5-FM and said his proposed budget will assure that the Transportation Trust Fund will remain solvent until June 2016. Christie did not mention the fund in his budget speech.
Christie's budget calls for dedicating $600 million to the fund from previously authorized but untapped borrowing.
Christie told host Eric Scott he isn't worried about adding to state debt to prop up the fund.

"You always bond for long-term construction projects. You always do. So, no, I don't think that's an enormous problem," Christie said. "Again, it's not in crisis at the moment. We're funded pretty well right now."

WASHINGTON – Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., says he will not attend Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's address to a joint meeting of Congress on March 3, citing a breach of diplomatic protocol by Republicans who invited him.

"The president of the United States heads up our foreign policy and the idea that the president wasn't even consulted — that is wrong and not a good thing for our country," Sanders said at a Monday appearance at the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank. "I am not going. I may watch it on TV, but I'm not going."
Sanders, an independent who caucuses with Democrats, is the first senator to say he will boycott the address. He is also mulling a 2016 presidential run.

The White House announced Friday that Vice President Biden will be traveling abroad and unable to attend. A handful of prominent House Democrats, including Rep. James Clyburn, D-S.C., and Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., have also announced they will not attend. More lawmakers are expected to follow suit.

House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., last month coordinated an invitation to Netanyahu with Israeli Ambassador Ron Dermer without consulting with the White House. President Obama and Netanyahu have had a tense relationship, particularly regarding ongoing international diplomatic relations with Iran to end its nuclear program.

Boehner announced the invitation the day after Obama's State of the Union address, in which he said Congress should not pass tougher sanctions on Iran while negotiations are ongoing. Netanyahu is deeply suspicions of the talks and has repeatedly spoken out about the danger Iran poses to Israel.

Congressional leaders are not required to consult the White House on such matters, but Democrats have chafed at the slight to the White House on the protocol and the timing, as it comes two weeks prior to Israeli elections and could be seen as in implicit U.S. endorsement of Netanyahu.

Dermer and Knesset Speaker Yuli Edelstein made the rounds on Capitol Hill last week in an effort to quell backlash about the handling of the address. Pelosi reaffirmed to reporters on Thursday support for Israel, noting the U.S. shares the same end goal to prevent a nuclear Iran.

"But this was really more about the casualness with which an invitation was extended to a head of state two weeks before his election, and politicizing deep convictions about the important relationship between Israel and the United States," she said.

PHOENIX — An international team led by researchers at Arizona State University has identified the oldest known fossil of the human genus, a discovery that marks a major new chapter in human evolution.
Researchers say the fossil, found by an ASU graduate student, is 2.8 million years old. That's about 400,000 years older than previous fossil records.

The team's finding was published Wednesday in the journal Science. The paper is receiving international attention because it further refines the period in which the genus Homo originated. The Homo group includes the species that eventually became modern humans, known as Homo sapiens, as well as others that went extinct.
The fossil is not as old as the famous, 3.2 million-year-old Lucy skeleton. Lucy belonged to an earlier, more ape-like species believed to be an ancestor of humans that went extinct.
The last evidence for Lucy's species is around 3 million years ago.
So the latest discovery narrows the gap to within 200,000 years between Lucy's species and the first appearance of the human genus 2.8 million years ago.
Researchers have long sought to determine when Homo originated, said ASU professor William Kimbel, director of ASU's Institute of Human Origins and one of the paper's lead authors.
But fossil records between 2 million and 3 million years have been scarce and not well preserved.
For more than 10 years, an international team led by ASU has searched for fossil specimens from that period in a remote part of Ethiopia known as the Ledi-Geraru research area.

On Jan. 29, 2013, ASU graduate student Chalachew Seyoum was exploring for fossils when he spotted part of a jaw eroding out of a hill. From years of field work, he knew the fossil was special. He pulled out one piece of the jaw, then another.
"Once I found the two pieces, I started calling everyone," he told The Arizona Republic. He said he and his colleagues began hugging in celebration when they realized what he had unearthed.
The two pieces of the jaw were re-assembled, cleaned and compared to previously discovered specimens.

Researchers first examined whether the fossil belonged to the same species as Lucy. The species, called Australopithecus afarensis, was discovered in 1974 and prompted a overhaul of the evolutionary tree. Lucy was discovered by Donald Johanson, who later founded the Institute of Human Origins, which is now at ASU.

Analysis of the jawbone ruled out a match to Lucy, though. The fossil had slim molars and an evenly proportioned jaw, features common in early human genus. Radioisotopes in a volcanic ash layer underlying the specimen dated the fossil to between 2.75 and 2.8 million years.
Kimbel said the fossil is probably a female because it has smaller teeth.

Even though scientists determined the fossil belonged to the Homo genus, there isn't enough information to assign a specific species. He said the jawbone has traits that are considered more primitive than Homo habilis species, one of the earliest species in Homo genus, which lived between 2.1 and 1.5 million years ago.
The female jaw could represent a population that gave rise to either Homo habilis or another species.

The finding is important because it's the earliest fossil discovered for the human genus. The discovery helps establish a trajectory for a genus that evolved to have larger brains and use tools, said Brian Villmoare, the paper's lead author.

"That was a big transition in human evolution. This is the first sort of inkling of this transition," said Villmoare, an assistant professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas who earned his doctorate at ASU.

A companion research paper published Wednesday in Science gives insight into what the environment may have been like during that time. Hippopotamus, crocodiles and fish fossils indicate rivers and/or lakes.
The habitat was likely open, with grass as far as the eye could see and few trees. The few trees that did exist likely ran along rivers or near the lake.
The landscape was similar to modern African habitats such as the Serengeti Plains.

Climate change around this time to a drier environment is one hypothesis for the appearance of the Homo species. Kaye Reed, ASU professor and research team co-leader, said it's too soon to make that determination. Researchers need a larger sample of fossils.
They continue to search the area.

TRENTON, N.J. — David Wildstein, who allegedly orchestrated the 2013 lane closures at the George Washington Bridge, will reportedly plead guilty to federal charges this week.

Wildstein was New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie's second-highest ranked staffer at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and the fallout from the week of intentional, crippling traffic jams severely damaged Christie's political aspirations. The reason for the traffic jams remains unclear, but emails have suggested that Wildstein and former Christie Deputy Chief of Staff Bridget Anne Kelly were seeking to punish Fort Lee's mayor.

Bloomberg reported Wildstein is scheduled to plead guilty Friday in U.S. District Court in Newark to a charging document known as a criminal information. It reported that the plea had originally been set for Thursday but was moved.

Christie, speaking with reporters at an unrelated news conference in New Brunswick, reiterated that he didn't know about the lane closures in advance. Of the prospect of Wildstein pleading guilty, the Republican governor said he doesn't know any details beyond the contents of the brief Bloomberg report.

"I don't expect that anything's going to be different than what I said on Jan. 9 because nothing's been different than what I said on Jan. 9," Christie said. "But I can't speculate as to what may happen or not happen. We'll see. Whenever anything does occur, we'll react to it. But I know what the truth is, so I'm not the least bit concerned about it."
A spokesman for U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman said the federal prosecutors' office will not be commenting.
Alan Zegas, Wildstein's attorney, did not immediately return a phone call and email seeking comment.

Wildstein, a former Livingston mayor who for years secretly ran the PolitickerNJ website under the pseudonym Wally Edge, was the second-in-command to Port Authority Deputy Director Bill Baroni from 2010 to 2013 in the newly created position of director of interstate capital projects. That position was eliminated after he was pushed out of the agency by Christie's office in December 2013.

Emails obtained through a subpoena by a General Assembly committee showed that in August 2013, Kelly sent an email to Wildstein telling him it was "time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee," which prompted him to direct the closure of two of the three lanes connecting traffic from local Fort Lee streets to the George Washington Bridge toll plaza. Fort Lee was not told in advance of the closures, and its efforts to contact agency officials were ignored for days.
NEW YORK – Terror suspect Khaled al-Fawwaz was convicted Thursday on conspiracy charges in the 1998 al-Qaeda bombings of U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania that killed 224.

A Manhattan federal court jury found the Saudi defendant guilty of four conspiracy charges relating to the killing of U.S. nationals, murder, destroying American buildings and property and attacking national defense utilities.
The verdict came after less than three days of deliberations by the 12-member panel.
The 52-year-old defendant faces a maximum sentence of life in prison with the outcome of the trial that began on Jan. 22, according to Manhattan U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara's office.

"As a unanimous jury has found, for nearly a decade, Khaled al-Fawwaz played a critical role for Al Qaeda in its murderous conspiracy against America," said Bharara. "We hope this verdict gives some comfort to Al Qaeda's victims around the world."

All 10 criminal defendants linked to the bombings in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam have now been convicted by trial or guilty plea in Manhattan federal court proceedings, prosecutors said. Co-defendant Abu Anas al-Libi died from cancer complications shortly before the trial of al-Fawwaz opened.

Prosecutors did not contend al-Fawwaz was directly involved in the embassy attacks. But they argued he was a trusted supporter of the late al-Qaeda mastermind Osama Bin Laden, and was implicated in the broader conspiracy surrounding the bombings.
He led a terror cell in Kenya and publicized Bin Laden's call to attack and kill Americans anywhere in the world, prosecutors charged.

Subsequently based in London, al-Fawwaz "served as bin Laden's bridge to the West in the pre-Internet era," disseminating the terror leader's statements and facilitating his media contacts, said Bharara

Bin Laden headed al-Qaeda at the time of the terror group's Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in New York City and Washington that killed nearly 3,000. He died in a 2011 attack U.S. Navy Seals led on his previously secret hideout in Abbottabad, Pakistan.

The defense team for al-Fawwaz conceded that he knew bin Laden. But they denied that he was an Al Qaeda operative and contended he was a peaceful man who had no role in the plot that led to the embassy bombings.

WASHINGTON — The fate of President Obama's health care law depends once again on how the Supreme Court interprets what Congress wrote — a task the justices have applied literally of late to laws affecting air, land and sea.

Four words in the 906-page statute will be the focus of the high court's attention March 4, when opponents argue that tax credits received by millions of Americans are legal only in health insurance markets "established by the State."

A literal reading of that phrase would seem to exclude health care exchanges operated by the federal government in 34 states. "It's a rather difficult textual argument for the government," said Kannon Shanmugam, who has argued 16 cases at the high court.

The government disputes that interpretation, calling the four-word phrase a "term of art" that includes federal exchanges, from which more than 9 million Americans have received subsidies. Excluding tax credits in federal exchanges "was never discussed" when the law was written, said former congressman George Miller, who chaired one of the committees that wrote the law.
"It was never whispered, never," said Rep. Sandy Levin, D-Mich., who chaired the House Ways and Means Committee when the law was passed.

Nearly five years after its enactment, the Supreme Court will have the final word — just as it did in 2012, when it upheld the law by a 5-4 vote. And in a number of unrelated cases recently that offer clues to the outcome, the justices have been practicing the art of "statutory interpretation." Translation: What were they thinking?

It's a question the justices have asked in cases featuring air marshals, cellphone towers, bank robbers and undersized red grouper — with mixed results. Often, plain language wins. Occasionally, the court demands context.

Taken together, the rulings and rhetoric should give Obamacare's proponents pause, for one reason: Chief Justice John Roberts — who rescued the law from being declared unconstitutional in his 2012 ruling — usually abides by the written word.
THE LETTER OF THE LAW

That was the case two weeks ago, when Roberts wrote the court's 7-2 majority opinion in favor of a former air marshal who leaked information about agency cutbacks. He said Robert MacLean's actions were not "specifically prohibited by law" — the relevant phrase in the Whistleblower Protection Act — because the prohibition was in a regulation, not a statute.

"Congress did not use the phrase 'law, rule or regulation' in the statutory language at issue here; it used the word 'law' standing alone," Roberts said. "That is significant, because Congress generally acts intentionally when it uses particular language in one section of a statute but omits it in another."

Notably, Justice Anthony Kennedy — who may be most likely to save Obamacare if Roberts does not — joined Justice Sonia Sotomayor's dissent. Since the law tasked the Transportation Security Administration with writing regulations, they reasoned, those regulations are prohibited under the law.
Roberts' affinity for the written word was apparent, too, when he dissented a week earlier in a case involving municipal disputes over locating cellphone towers.

The Telecommunications Act specifies that a local government's denial of a cell tower application "shall be in writing." The court ruled 6-3 that such notice also must come in a timely fashion. Roberts said the issue of timing represents "a requirement found nowhere in the text of the statute."

"The city here fully complied with its obligations under the statute," Roberts said. "It issued its decision in writing, and it submitted a written record containing — so far as we know — substantial evidence supporting that decision."
A FISH AS 'OBJECT' LESSON?

The full court's devotion to language was apparent that same week, when it ruled unanimously that a bank robber could face more time in prison for forcing a woman to walk with him from one room to another.

The 79-year-old woman, Mary Parnell, then suffered a heart attack and died after the short stroll. But what mattered was the 80-year-old federal law's establishment of added penalties if a bank robber "forces any person to accompany him" during the crime.

"In 1934, just as today, to 'accompany' someone meant to 'go with' him," Justice Antonin Scalia wrote. "English literature is replete with examples." He went on to quote Charles Dickens and Jane Austen.
Lest the court's verve for vocabulary appear to doom the health care law, however, the justices aren't always so exacting.

That seemed apparent in early November, when a government lawyer argued that a federal law aimed at white-collar criminals who destroy evidence was used properly to prosecute a Florida fisherman who dumped undersized fish into the Gulf of Mexico.
The law, passed in 2002 to crack down on the type of document shredding that occurred in the Enron scandal, criminalizes the destruction of a "record, document or tangible object."
"If you stop someone on the street and ask them, 'Is a fish a tangible object?' the answer would almost certainly be '­­yes,'" assistant solicitor general Roman Martinez said during oral arguments.
"Well," Roberts replied skeptically, "what if you stopped them on the street and said, 'Is a fish record, document or tangible object?'"

WASHINGTON — Embattled Sen. Robert Menendez will have a diminished role when he returns to the Senate next week. But he probably won't speak with a diminished voice when a key committee takes up his bill on Iran.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will vote Tuesday on legislation Menendez co-authored that would give Congress the option of rejecting any nuclear deal that might be reached with Iran.
President Obama has threatened to veto the measure.

The New Jersey Democrat, known for bucking the Obama administration on Iran and other issues, has lost some influence over the steering bill through committee after temporarily stepping down from his post as the panel's top Democrat to battle federal bribery charges, said Ilan Goldenberg, a fellow at the Center for a New American Security.
But Menendez will remain a member of the committee and is expected to be as vocal as ever in pushing for passage of his bill.
"I've never known him to be somebody who's going to be shy when he has a strong view," said Goldenberg, a former senior Foreign Relations Committee staff member.

The bill, co-authored by Foreign Relations Chairman Bob Corker, R-Tenn., would give Congress 60 days to approve, disapprove or take no action on any comprehensive agreement the administration and its international allies strike with Iran to curb the country's nuclear ambitions.

Obama would be barred from suspending congressional sanctions on Iran during the 60-day period. The legislation also would require that Congress be notified quickly if Iran breaches the agreement, so lawmakers could vote to restore sanctions.

The White House says diplomacy is the best way to address Iran's nuclear ambitions. White House press secretary Josh Earnest said recently that "at a minimum," Congress shouldn't vote before June 30 — the deadline for a final deal — on legislation the White House believes would undermine the ability of the U.S. and its international allies to reach a diplomatic solution.
But Menendez has continued to push for congressional oversight, even after the administration announced a framework agreement with Iran on April 2.

"If diplomats can negotiate for two-years on this issue, then certainly Congress is entitled to a review period of an agreement that will fundamentally alter our relationship with Iran and the sanctions imposed by Congress," Menendez said in a statement after the announcement. "The best outcome remains a good deal that ends Iran's illicit nuclear weapons program. That requires a strong, united, and bipartisan approach from the administration and Congress."

As the bill's supporters approach a veto-proof majority in the Senate, the White House has stepped up efforts to promote the framework agreement and win over lawmakers. Some key Democrats are working to modify the bill.

"I want to make sure that it's clear that this bill is a congressional review-and-notification bill and not one that takes on directly the substance of the agreements being negotiated," Sen. Benjamin Cardin, the committee's new ranking Democrat from Maryland, said during a Wednesday interview.

Menendez, a staunch supporter of Israel, has long advocated a tough approach to dealing with Iran. He pushed for strong sanctions on Iran's central bank that the White House ultimately credited with helping bring Iran to the negotiating table.

More recently, Menendez co-sponsored another bipartisan bill, over Obama's veto threat, to impose additional economic sanctions on Iran if international negotiations don't yield a final deal by June 30 to curtail the country's nuclear program. He accused administration officials of using talking points "straight out of Tehran" in their negotiations.

The son of Cuban immigrants, Menendez "despises" authoritarian regimes and believes the U.S. is giving too much ground to the Iranians, said Mark Dubowitz, executive director of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies.

The success of the previous sanctions Menendez pushed gives him "significant moral authority on this issue as well as a deep substantive knowledge base that still provides him with significant legitimacy and influence with his colleagues," said Dubowitz, who supports the congressional review bill.

The bill wouldn't hurt negotiations, Dubowitz said, because it would establish "a group of bad cops" in Congress that "U.S. negotiators can use as leverage to counter (Iran's) supreme leader and his red lines."

Goldenberg disagreed, saying the bill would shake Iranians' confidence the U.S. will live up to a deal. But he said Menendez, who voted against the war in Iraq, has been unfairly painted as a war hawk.
"He definitely comes at it from a view that sanctions and more pressure are the most effective way to get Iran to make the necessary concessions," Goldenberg said.
At age 94, Berkley Bedell still has plenty of fight in him. And he's trying to hook Iowans just starting to vote.

Bedell represented western Iowa in Congress from 1975 to 1986, before most college students were born. Yet he's urging them to push presidential candidates to take on three big issues: climate change, money in politics and student costs and debt.

Why those three topics? "If you are a young person, your life will be affected by whether we do something about climate change," he said. And unless we change the political system and take money out of politics, nothing will get done, Bedell explained to Register editors last week.

College campuses will soon be crawling with candidates plying dining halls and auditoriums. Students are easier to reach in some ways than other groups, although actually getting them to the caucuses or the polls is another story.
Candidates and activists all across the political spectrum hope to change this.

"If we want the Instagram generation to get up off their sofas, to leave their dorm rooms and vote, someone needs to come forward and make it worth their while," U.S. Sen. Rand Paul said in a speech April 10 in Iowa City.
So I asked a student active in politics to help us old guys out.

Austin Jacobs is chair of the Simpson College Republicans from Auburn, Ia. He'll graduate a semester early, in December, with hopes of working for a campaign in 2016 and then going on to business and law school at Drake. His advice for candidates and activists:

Don't assume all students are apathetic. A survey Jacobs' class did shows that Simpson students are more politically active than their peers, he said. Nor do they fit in neat categories: Many are both socially liberal and fiscally conservative, he said.

Accept an invitation to have small, intimate gatherings. "Don't be afraid to sit with students," Jacobs said. So far, Donald Trump and Martin O'Malley have visited Simpson's campus and met with students.

Be prepared to address all sorts of issues. "In my opinion, if you come, talk to as adults," Jacobs said. "Don't only talk about student loans. I want to know where you stand on immigration, ISIS, other issues."
Evan Burger of the U.S. Student Association adds another thought: Listen to students to determine their interests, instead of pushing your own agenda on them.
"Students want the face-to-face interactions that the caucuses are known for," he said. Burger, who is based in Des Moines, has been organizing students on campuses while working with Bedell.

Bedell, from Spirit Lake, now spends most of his time in Naples, Fla. He was in Iowa last week, including speaking to student activists from several Iowa universities at Grinnell College. He calls his campaign the "Dream Team Proposal" (he's also working with former U.S. Sen. Tom Harkin).
His goal includes getting a pledge from candidates to address the following issues:
Climate change: This includes a $50-per-ton tax on carbon, which would be returned to citizens in an annual payment.
Money in politics: He wants a constitutional amendment to rescind the Supreme Court's Citizens United ruling that removed many limits on campaign contributions.

Student loans: This includes expanding Pell grants to include all students at nonprofit colleges, and proposing the federal government pay off all outstanding student loans over a four- to -five year period.

To pay for the student proposal, Bedell repeats his mantra: "Tax the wealthy." If that doesn't raise enough, tax them some more, he urged. The proposals include an annual 5 percent tax on family wealth over $10 million, taxes on derivatives and other taxes.

For years, Bedell has fought tax cuts for the rich, even when those policies benefited him personally. One of Iowa's most successful entrepreneurs, he started selling fishing tackle when he was a teenager. His company was the largest fishing tackle company in the nation by the time it was sold in 2007.
His latest quest seems quixotic. Perhaps Bedell is tilting his fishing pole at windmills, but you have to admire his passion. And that still sells, at any age.
Lynn Hicks is the Register's opinion and engagement editor. Follow him on Twitter at @lynnhicks
Prince has now added a fourth show at the Louisville Palace, on Sunday at 11 p.m. At this rate, he might as well stick around for March Madness.
Tickets are on sale now at LiveNation.com for $80, $100, $150 and $250.

The shows will kick off Prince's Hit & Run Tour, and the Louisville shows have been promoted as parties in honor of 3RDEYEGIRL drummer Hannah Welton, a Louisville native and graduate of the Louisville Leopard Percussionists.
The Hit & Run Tour is classic Prince in that shows are announced very near the performance date. It traveled the United Kingdom last year with a series of critically-acclaimed shows.
Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.
Whether or not world powers reach a nuclear understanding with Iran this week, Congress and world leaders will try to influence the ongoing negotiations until a final deadline at the end of June.

Negotiators for the United States, United Kingdom, France, Russia, China and Germany have been unable to agree with Iran on principles of a deal to limit Iran's nuclear program in return for the lifting of crippling economic sanctions. Their differences are so pronounced they extended a Tuesday deadline for a framework agreement to Thursday after a week of talks in Lausanne, Switzerland.
Either way, Iran's nuclear program will be a priority in several arenas until the next deadline arrives.
U.S. CONGRESS

Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress have pledged to push for a vote on two bills that would increase pressure on Iran. One bill, sponsored by Sens. Robert Menendez, D-N.J., and Bob Corker, R-Tenn., would give a skeptical Congress authority to approve any deal. The other would increase sanctions on Iran after June 30 if there is no comprehensive agreement at that time. President Obama has said he would veto the bills because they would derail the talks.
The wrangling will begin in earnest April 13, when lawmakers return from recess and decide whether the results of the past week's talks were satisfactory, and how to proceed.

Gary Samore, a former arms control coordinator for Obama, said he expects both bills to pass but not survive a presidential veto. The emergence of Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., as the next Senate Democratic leader could complicate matters and give administration skeptics more clout, said Mark Dubowitz, executive director of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, who has testified before Congress on Iran sanctions.

Schumer, who's expressed skepticism of the emerging deal, is being lobbied heavily by both his pro-Israel constituents and the White House, Dubowitz said. "He'll be the bellwether for which way wavering Democrats go on this," he said.
ISRAEL

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a critic of any deal that leaves Iran's nuclear program intact, is likely to continue lobbying Congress and U.S. allies at the talks and across the Middle East to harden their negotiating stance.

"Now is the time for the international community to insist on a better deal," Netanyahu said Wednesday. "The concessions offered to Iran in Lausanne would ensure a bad deal that would endanger Israel, the Middle East and the peace of the world."

A better deal would link the lifting of the restrictions on Iran's nuclear program to changes in the nation's behavior, including an end to aggression in the region, as well as its support of terrorists around the world and its threats to annihilate Israel, he said.

Israel could also complicate the talks by taking action against Iranian nuclear scientists and facilities, which it's suspected of attacking in the past. That would make it politically harder for the Iranians to compromise with Western demands, said George Perkovich, an expert on nuclear proliferation at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
FINALIZING THE DETAILS

The difficult talks this week in Switzerland left many details to be ironed out. There's still no agreement on the pace of sanctions relief, whether Iran will explain evidence of a past nuclear weapons program — which it denies — and how its adherence to a deal will be monitored.

Since some details that were agreed to in principle in past talks were rejected this week — such as a plan to ship Iran's uranium stockpiles to Russia — everything is still "up in the air," Dubowitz said.
JUNE 30 DEADLINE?

The talks have proceeded under a six-month agreement signed in November 2013 that has been extended several times already and is now due to expire June 30. Just as Tuesday's latest deadline passed, the next one could be too.

From the U.S. standpoint, keeping the 2013 interim agreement in place is an advantage, because it stops Iran from advancing its nuclear program and building its stockpiles of nuclear fuel, while depriving Iran of significant economic relief, Samore said.
"There are many problems that could easily make it difficult to get an agreement by June 30," Samore said. "At that point I would expect another extension."
Dubowitz agrees.
"There is no such thing as a deadline in these negotiations," he said. "The only deadline I think the president is concerned about is January 2017, when his second term as president expires."
WASHINGTON — President Obama ordered the federal government Thursday to cut greenhouse emissions by 40% over the next decade, and said he hopes private businesses and other nations will follow suit.
The executive order signed by Obama also directed the government to increase its use of renewable resources to 30% of energy use.
"These are ambitious goals, but we know that they're achievable goals," Obama told reporters after he examined the solar panel technology at the U.S. Department of Energy.

In addition, the White House said that several major federal suppliers — including IBM, General Electric, Northrop Grumman and Honeywell — have committed to their own reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.Obama met with some of those suppliers during his trip to the energy department.
More businesses and homeowners should use cleaner energy, Obama said, not just "because it's simply good for the environment, but because it's good for their bottom lines."
Obama issued the order as he prepares to meet Thursday afternoon with Prince Charles of the United Kingdom, a proponent of climate change legislation.
The United States and allies are also hoping to forge a global climate treaty by the end of the year.
After signing his latest executive order, Obama said that "we thought it was important for us to lead by example here at the federal government."

Phoenix Mayor Greg Stanton gave his fourth annual State of the City speech before a crowd of business and political leaders at the Sheraton Phoenix Downtown Hotel on Wednesday. The speech comes at a crucial political moment for Stanton as he enters the final year of his first term and faces re-election in August.
He is also campaigning for voter approval of a transportation tax hike — a move that would greatly expand the city's transit system and could be a key piece of Stanton's legacy.
Read the entire speech as it was written

But his speech also comes at a challenging time for Phoenix, as the city stares down years of potential red ink largely resulting from rising pension costs. Stanton also is tasked with leading a City Council fractured by ideological and personal divisions. At the same time, the city is working to rebuild its shrunken police force.
See our reporters tweeting live:
What to expect in the speech:
Stanton may not address all of those issues, but here are five things to watch for in his speech:

1. Legacy building: Stanton has plenty of political capital riding on the fate of the city's transportation ballot question facing voters in the Aug. 25 election. Expect him to make the economic case for a more robust light-rail and bus system. Stanton is urging support for the 0.7 percent sales tax — an increase over Phoenix's current 0.4 percent transportation tax that's set to expire in 2020.

The tax hike would fund road repairs and an expansion of the city's light-rail and bus systems over 35 years. The $31.7 billion price tag of the plan, with local and federal funds, has been a political wedge, and critics say it unwisely spends billions on light rail. Watch to see whether Stanton directly addresses concerns about the cost.

2. Playing the centrist card: In past State of the City speeches, Stanton has played to his base in the Democratic Party, emphasizing hot-button issues, from gun safety to gay rights. But Stanton's agenda has taken a more centrist turn in the past year, starting with his 2014 State of the City speech, which focused on creating an ideas-based economy. Don't expect him to check his party colors at the door, but the economy and transportation infrastructure likely will take center stage.
RELATED: Phoenix budget adds services despite future risks

3. Fiscal reality check: Will Stanton mention the city's troubled financial state? As pension costs soar, Phoenix projects it could face years of budget deficits starting in the 2016-17 fiscal year. The city expects a balanced budget in the upcoming fiscal year only because City Manager Ed Zuercher has proposed putting off making the city's full payments to the state public-safety pension system — a move that would cost taxpayers millions more over the long run. Stanton didn't address the city's strained finances during last year's speech. If he passes on the issue again, criticism from his opponents could be swift and sharp.

4. Surprise announcements: Stanton has tried to spice up his past State of the City speeches with high-profile announcements about economic development or initiatives coming to the city. Two years ago, for example, he announced that the Police Department would conduct the largest gun buyback in Arizona history. There could be several announcements in the hopper this year, particularly as the city focuses on business recruitment and efforts to increase exports.

5. Friendly shout-outs, or fiery shutouts: Watch for Stanton to heap praise on some of his City Council colleagues. Stanton is likely to have kind words for council allies, such as Daniel Valenzuela, Kate Gallego and Laura Pastor. But who he doesn't mention can say even more about the status of relations within City Hall. Also, don't be surprised if the mayor has some critical words for political leaders at the state level. As one of the most visible Democrats in the state, Stanton has often opposed the state's position on issues such as immigration, gay rights and the environment.

Residents who want to attend Wednesday's speech must register for a ticket, and won't be able to attend the luncheon portion. Those interested in attending should e-mail the Greater Phoenix Chamber of Commerce, which hosts the event annually, to reserve a seat: events@phoenixchamber.com.

DETROIT — An 87-year-old man who hit a fuel tanker while changing lanes last month on a Michigan interstate is responsible for the ensuing crash near the Dearborn-Detroit border that created fireball explosions and closed eastbound lanes for several days, police said.

The man, whose identity wasn't immediately released, was driving his car eastbound on Interstate 94 in the right lane March 11 when he went to change lanes and collided with the tanker operated by a 55-year-old Redford Township, Mich., man.

The car spun in front of the truck, causing the truck to travel into the left lane, striking a third vehicle and forcing it into oncoming traffic lanes, according to a report Michigan State Police released Wednesday.
The tanker was carrying 13,000 gallons of diesel and unleaded fuel, and the large explosions emitted black smoke plumes visible for miles before crews had the fire under control.
No one was killed, and only minor injuries were reported. The third vehicle in the crash was driven by a 23-year-old woman and police said all three vehicles were totaled in the fires.
The 87-year-old man was found to be at fault, but police didn't specify what penalties he could face.

The popular highway's eastbound lanes were closed for a few days so crews could replace a section of pavement about 150 feet long. A substantial cleanup was necessary, as fuel had leaked into a nearby sewer system and areas near the crash.
Republican efforts to replace the federal health law have been given new urgency by the Supreme Court.
As soon as this spring, the court could invalidate health insurance subsidies available to millions of Americans if it rules for the challengers in the King v. Burwell case.

Republicans who hate the Affordable Care Act are rooting for the court to do what they have been unable to accomplish — dismantle a key part of the law. But as the party that controls Congress, some Republicans also fear the potential for a backlash if they don't have a plan to help those who would effectively be stripped of coverage, many of whom are voters in Republican-led states.

There's another reason to agree soon on a replacement for the law, instead of continuing their long campaign to repeal it. If Republicans present a reasonable alternative, it could help swing a justice or two who might otherwise worry about the possible ramifications of cutting off the subsidies. Or so the reasoning goes.

"The Republicans would love to give the justices some comfort that if they rule against the Obama administration, there will be something there to deal with the fallout," says Dean Clancy, a Republican strategist and former aide to House Majority Leader Dick Armey.

Those pushing the case argue that language in the law limits help to pay for insurance to residents of states that have established their own health insurance exchanges. So far only 13 states have — the rest use the federal healthcare.gov exchange. The administration contends that Congress clearly intended that the subsidy — tax credits based on income — be available in all states, and has declined to discuss any possible contingency plans.

If the court rules against the administration, the impact will fall heavily on Republican-led states, such as Florida and Texas, that didn't create their own exchanges, increasing pressure on Congress to act.

"I really do believe that this situation has concentrated the minds of many people on (Capitol) Hill," says Avik Roy, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute and a former health advisor to GOP presidential candidate Mitt Romney. If the Supreme Court rules that subsidies cannot be provided through the federal health exchange, he says, Republicans in the House and Senate "realize if they don't do something, they will be held accountable for that. Because they are running Congress now, they can't blame it on the Democrats."

Still, putting something on the front burner does not guarantee it will get done. Republicans have been vowing to "repeal and replace" the Affordable Care Act almost since it became law in 2010. So far, the GOP-controlled House has held more than 50 separate votes to repeal or otherwise cancel parts of the law. Replacing it, however, has been another story.

"Republicans are united around repeal. And they're united around replace. But obviously they're not united around 'replace with what,'" says Dean Rosen, a health policy consultant who was a top aide to GOP Senate Majority Leader Bill Frist and to the House Ways and Means Committee.

Republican health strategist Terry Holt, a former aide to the GOP House leadership, agrees. He says Republicans "are serious about a replacement" for the Affordable Care Act, "but it's the law, and it's harder to change law than to make it."

There are several efforts underway to come up with a consensus Republican alternative to the health law. The repeal bill the House approved Feb. 3 includes language requiring the four main committees that handle health legislation in that chamber to approve a replacement, but no time limit is specified. Separately, three of those committee chairmen were tasked by House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy in January to come up with a health bill, again with no specific deadline.

Across the Capitol, two GOP senators with deep backgrounds in health — Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Richard Burr, R-N.C. — along with House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, R-Mich. have unveiled the outlines of a plan that was first floated last year.

And House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, R-Wis., has said Republicans in the House are working on a short-term "bridge" for those who could get stripped of their insurance subsidies, although again, no specifics have been offered.
Even with new incentives, getting to specifics won't be easy, says Clancy, for much the same reasons that have kept Republicans from being able to agree on a health overhaul the past five years.

Still, the prospect of millions of people in states run by Republican governors and Republican legislatures losing their insurance could be the deciding factor, says Holt. "These are people who have been promised something and are expecting it to continue, and it's hard to see how you cut people off," he says.
Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent program of the Kaiser Family Foundation.
WASHINGTON — Earl Agan was no fan of the North American Free Trade Agreement that Bill Clinton signed into law in 1993.

Today, the Iowa labor union member is worried about what a massive pact being negotiated by the Obama administration with 11 Asia-Pacific nations would do for working men and women. Agan would like to hear more from presidential candidates — Democrat and Republican — about where they stand on free trade and the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which President Obama says would benefit the U.S. economy.
"NAFTA didn't do us any good. Working men and women across the country got the shaft," said Agan, president of the Central Iowa Building and Construction Trades Council.

Agan illustrates the challenge for Hillary Clinton, as she is pressured by potential presidential rivals such as Martin O'Malley and Bernie Sanders and some in the Democratic Party's base to speak out against the trade pact and the underlying "fast track" authority Obama needs to complete the deal. Obama is siding with pro-trade Republicans and arguing with Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., a liberal favorite.

As secretary of State, Clinton referred to the Trans-Pacific Partnership as the "gold standard in trade agreements." She wrote in her memoir, Hard Choices, that the trade deal "was also important for American workers, who would benefit from competing on a more level playing field" and called it "a strategic initiative that would strengthen the position of the United States in Asia."

Clinton, however, was careful last week during a campaign trip to New Hampshire to not say definitively whether she was for or against the trade pact. Jeb Bush, a potential GOP rival, charges that she is flip-flopping.

"Any trade deal has to produce jobs and raise wages and increase prosperity and protect our security," she said. "We have to do our part in making sure we have the capabilities and the skills to be competitive."
Agan, the Iowa union member, says he's inclined to support O'Malley, who targeted Clinton in a video blasting "bad trade deals."

The AFL-CIO, the nation's largest union with 12.5 million members, outlined an agenda Tuesday for presidential candidates in both parties demanding a commitment to addressing income inequality and raising wages for workers. On the issues of trade and fast-track authority, AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka minced no words.

"The labor movement opposes fast track. We expect those who seek to lead our nation to also oppose fast track," Trumka said in a speech billed as a major address to evaluate the 2016 field. "There's no middle ground ... There will be no place to hide."
Roger Hickey, co-director of the progressive Campaign for America's Future, said it's time for Clinton to make a clear statement.
"This is an opportunity for her to talk about the current state of the world economy and to stake out her own positions on what's acceptable and unacceptable in a trade treaty," Hickey said.
Obama defended Clinton for not taking a clear stance on the Trans-Pacific Partnership, during an interview Monday with The Wall Street Journal.

"I think she said what she should be saying, which is she is going to want to see a trade agreement that is strong on labor, strong on the environment, helps U.S. workers, helps the U.S. economy. That's my standard as well, and I'm confident that standard can be met," Obama said.
While membership in labor unions has been declining for years, these organizations still have political clout — especially when it comes to getting out the vote in states such as Ohio and Michigan.
Union members made up 18% of the electorate in 2012 — down from 2008 and 2004 — but Obama won 58% of their support, according to exit polls.

Peter Francia, a political science professor at East Carolina University, said trade is not a make or break vote for all union members. A teacher or a government worker may not view the issue in the same way that someone in construction does, he said.

"The unions have limited options in terms of where they can go," said Francia, author of The Future of Organized Labor in Politics. "They do not want to see a Republican in the White House … Hillary Clinton will agree with organized labor on more than enough things to satisfy them."
Follow @ccamia on Twitter.

The sounds of 50 Harley-Davidson motorcycles rumbling nearby almost shook Rich Teerlink's glass of red wine. The man who helped turned Harley-Davidson into the elite luxury brand it is today had to step outside to see what the ruckus was about.
"All of a sudden I hear these sounds and I think it's two bikes," said Teerlink, who served as Harley-Davidson's CEO from 1989 to 1997. "Then I say, 'No, that's more than two bikes."

About 50 Naples Harley-Davidson riders surprised Teerlink, a Sanibel resident, at his Thursday retirement party from Vertex Inc., board. Vertex, which holds some of its meetings in Naples, is a leading provider of corporate enterprise tax solutions and services. The riders, along with Naples Harley-Davidson general manager John Tabar, thanked the 73-year-old Teerlink for lifting the motorcycle's quality and brand.

Harley-Davidson had a poor reputation, falling market share, and faced significant losses when Teerlink took over the company in 1989. Teerlink and a small band of executives led a corporate revolution that ultimately created a world-class motorcycle company and inspired a nation of devoted fans.

"We are always looking for a reason to ride and Vertex gave us a great one," Tabar said. "Rich Teerlink brought quality back to Harley-Davidson and reliability. He made it a brand that was a step above everybody else. It's an elite luxury brand and Rich had a big role in that."
After leaving Harley, Teerlink served 13 years on the Vertex board of directors. His last day was Wednesday.

Vertex wanted to make his retirement party special at the Naples Grande Beach Resort by inviting the bikers from the Naples Harley-Davidson dealership. The riders agreed to ride for Teerlink as long as Vertex made a contribution to the March of Dimes charity.
Vertex gave each of the riders a T-shirt, which showed a bespectacled Teerlink on top of a Harley-Davidson. Teerlink remains as passionate for Harley-Davidson.

"These are Harley folks and Harley folks are good people," Teerlink said as he signed autographs of his Harley-Davidson book. "Do this test for me. Find a car broken down on the road and I will give you odds you will find a Harley-Davidson rider parked right there helping that person out."

Teerlink is the author of "More Than a Motorcycle," the leadership journey at Harley-Davidson, and has been a frequent speaker to corporate audiences, including having addressed Vertex customers as a keynote speaker at Vertex Exchange.

"This is an amazing thing," Teerlink said about the riders joining his party. "I never imagined something like this happening. I almost walked away when I saw all these people coming. But then I saw all the Harleys and I said I can be here. Harley folks are good people."
The framework nuclear agreement announced Thursday between world powers and Iran sets the stage for Congress and foreign nations to try to change — or kill — a final deal.
The United States, United Kingdom, France, Russia, China and Germany reached an understanding with Iran on limits to Iran's nuclear program in return for lifting crippling economic sanctions.

Negotiators now have until June 30 to fill in the critical details to assure Iran it will get relief from the sanctions as soon as possible, and guarantee the world powers that Iran won't develop a nuclear weapon. Lying in wait are Congress, Iran's enemies in the Middle East and difficult issues that may reshape, delay or doom a final accord.
U.S. Congress

President Obama wants a final agreement that is short of a formal treaty to skirt approval by a skeptical Congress, which might make changes unacceptable to Iran. Not so fast, lawmakers say. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will take up legislation that requires congressional approval of a nuclear deal, committee Chairman Bob Corker, R-Tenn., said.

"If a final agreement is reached, the American people, through their elected representatives, must have the opportunity to weigh in to ensure the deal truly can eliminate the threat of Iran's nuclear program and hold the regime accountable," Corker said.
Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., who has co-sponsored the bill and had expressed skepticism as the deal was emerging, said he'll "be giving the framework a very careful look."

Schumer's emergence as the next Senate Democratic leader could give critics — now mostly Republicans — more clout, said Mark Dubowitz, executive director of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, who has testified before Congress on Iran sanctions.
Schumer is being lobbied heavily by both his pro-Israel constituents and the White House, Dubowitz said. "He'll be the bellwether for which way wavering Democrats go on this."
A second Senate bill would increase sanctions on Iran after June 30 if there is no comprehensive agreement by then. Obama has said he would veto both bills because they would derail the talks.

The wrangling begins April 14, when Corker's committee will debate whether the results of the past week's talks were satisfactory, and discuss how to proceed. One option that Obama fears could kill the deal: new sanctions to squeeze additional concessions from Iran. Instead, Obama has warned, Iran may walk away from the talks and accelerate its nuclear program.
Israel

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a vehement opponent of any deal that leaves Iran's nuclear program intact, has already launched a fresh round of sharp attacks. He's trying to rally Congress, other world powers and Iran's rivals in the Middle East — such as Saudi Arabia, which also has qualms about the deal — to demand a stronger deal that ensures Iran won't develop a nuclear bomb in secret.

"This deal will both threaten us and threaten our neighbors," Netanyahu said Sunday on CNN's State of the Union.Netanyahu — who also appeared on NBC's Meet The Press and ABC's This Week — said the proposal will leave Iran's nuclear infrastructure in place.

Netanyahu said the United States and its allies should intensify economic sanctions on Iran to force it to give up more of its nuclear program. He also questioned the effectiveness of inspections, saying Iran has cheated in the past. "I'm not trying to kill any deal," Netanyahu said on NBC. "I'm trying to kill a bad deal."

In his weekend radio address, Obama said cheating by Iran would not go undetected: "International inspectors will have unprecedented access to Iran's nuclear program because Iran will face more inspections than any other country in the world. If Iran cheats, the world will know it."

Israel could disrupt the negotiations by assassinating Iran's nuclear scientists and sabotaging or attacking its nuclear facilities, which Iran has accused Israel of doing in the past. That could scuttle a final deal, said George Perkovich, an expert on nuclear proliferation at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
Details

The framework agreement left key details to be ironed out, including the pace of sanctions relief, when and to what extent Iran will explain evidence of a past nuclear weapons program — which it denies ever having — and when it will take the steps spelled out in the deal.
The Obama administration and Iran showed they interpret the deal differently just within a few hours of its announcement.

Secretary of State John Kerry said that "in return for Iran's future cooperation," relief from U.S. and international sanctions will be provided "in phases." Iran could begin qualifying for such relief as soon as four months to a year after any agreement begins, Kerry said.

Iran's Foreign Minister Javad Zarif, however, tweeted a response that denied sanctions relief would be gradual. "Iran/5+1 Statement: "US will cease the application of ALL nuclear-related secondary economic and financial sanctions." Is this gradual?"
Deadline

The talks have proceeded under a six-month agreement signed in November 2013 that has been extended several times already and is now due to expire in three months. Just as Tuesday's self-imposed deadline was missed by two days, the June 30 deadline could be postponed, too.

From the U.S. standpoint, keeping the 2013 interim agreement now in force is an advantage, because it stops Iran from advancing its nuclear program and building its stockpiles of nuclear fuel, while depriving Iran of significant economic relief, said Gary Samore, a former arms control coordinator for Obama.
"There are many problems that could easily make it difficult to get an agreement by June 30," Samore said. "At that point I would expect another extension."

Dubowitz agrees. "There is no such thing as a deadline in these negotiations," he said. "The only deadline I think the president is concerned about is January 2017, when his second term as president expires."

WASHINGTON — President Obama's chief of staff told a Jewish lobbying group Monday that remarks by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu disavowing a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict were "troubling."

"We cannot simply pretend that those comments were never made, or that they don't raise questions about the prime minister's commitment to achieving peace through direct negotiations," Denis McDonough told J Street's national conference.
McDonough's speech to the moderate pro-Israel lobbying group represented just the latest fallout from an Israeli election that has shaken up its relations with the United States.

The Obama administration has taken particular exception to Netanyahu's election-eve comment that a Palestinian state would not happen as long as he was prime minister. Netanyahu attempted to clarify his remarks after seemingly winning enough seats in the parliament to put together a governing coalition for another term last week, and now says that what's changed is the Palestinian commitment to the peace process.
But McDonough said that the damage was already done, saying "such contradictory comments call into question his commitment to a two-state solution."
McDonough denied suggestions that that Obama's objection to Netanyahu's remarks was a matter of "personal pique."

"Nothing could be further from the truth," McDonough said. "America's commitment to a two-state solution is fundamental to U.S. foreign policy. It's been the goal of both Republican and Democratic presidents, and it remains our goal today, because it is the only way to secure Israel's future as a Jewish and democratic state."
Netahyahu also apologized Monday for an election-day video in which he tried to motivate conservatives to vote by saying Arab Israelis were being bused to the polls "in droves."

After meeting with minority groups at the prime minister's residence, Netanyahu said he didn't intend to insult Arab Israelis and said he would be prime minister for "all Israeli citizens, without any difference of religion, race, or gender."
White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said he hadn't seen Netanyahu's apology, but "if that's what he said, then it certainly seems appropriate for him to make that acknowledgement."
Follow @gregorykorte on Twitter.
Scientists on Tuesday said they believe they have found the remains of Spanish literary giant Miguel de Cervantes.

The author of Don Quixote, regarded as a literary masterpiece, was buried in the Barefoot Trinitarians convent in the Spanish capital of Madrid in 1616. His remains were lost when the convent was rebuilt and his grave moved later in the 17th century.
In January, archaeologists found fragments of a casket bearing the initials "M.C." and bones but did not say if they were that of the writer dubbed the "Prince of Letters."

Forensic anthropologist Francisco Etxeberria on Tuesday said experts believe Cervantes' bones are among the remains of 15 bodies found in the crypt, but cannot definitively prove which ones were the writer's, the Associated Press reported. The researchers said there is no DNA evidence.
Forensic scientist Almudena Garcia Rubio said: "The remains are in a bad state of conservation and do not allow us to do an individual identification of Miguel de Cervantes," the BBC reported.
"But we are sure what the historical sources say is the burial of Miguel de Cervantes and the other people buried with him is what we have found."
Investigator Luis Avial told a news conference that Cervantes, who died age 69, would be reburied in the convent "with full honors" after a new tomb is built, according to the BBC.
"Cervantes asked to be buried there and there he should stay," expert Luis Avial said.
The son of a surgeon, Cervantes was born in 1547 in Alcalá de Henares, near Madrid, and studied philosophy and literature in Italy before becoming a soldier and losing his left hand in battle.
He published the first part of Don Quixote in 1605. The work, considered the first modern novel, has been translated into more than 60 different languages.

For 70 years, Anne Frank was believed to have died of typhus in Bergen-Belsen just two weeks before allied forces liberated the Nazi death camp on April 15, 1945.

On Tuesday, however, new research released by the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam concludes that the 15-year-old Jewish diarist and her older sister, Margot, more likely died in February, not on March 31. The Dutch government fixed that date at the end of World War II after the Red Cross concluded Anne and her sister died sometime between March 1 and March 31.
The researchers based their new findings on eyewitness testimonies of survivors and the archives of the Bergen-Belsen Memorial, Red Cross and the International Tracing Service.
"It is unlikely that they were still alive in March; their deaths must have occurred in February 1945," the Anne Frank House said.
The exact date of their deaths remains unknown.
"One day they simply weren't there anymore," one camp survivor who was friends with the girls told the researchers.

Annelies Marie Frank's famous diary tells of hiding with her family and other Jews in secret rooms behind a bookcase in the house that is now her museum. After two years of hiding, they were betrayed to the Nazi occupiers, and she, Margot and their mother were shipped by train to Auschwitz-Birkenau in early September 1944. Two months later, Anne and Margot were transferred to Bergen-Belsen.
In early December, Nanaette Blitz, a former classmate who was transferred to the overcrowded camp, told of finding Anne, saying it was a miracle they recognized one another.

"She was no more than a skeleton by then," Blitz recounted. "She was wrapped in a blanket; she couldn't bear to wear her clothes anymore because they were crawling with lice." Lice are the main carrier of typhus, the symptoms of which include severe headaches, muscle pain, high fever, followed by skin rash and delirium.

The last time Blitz saw her was January 1945, when typhus was epidemic in the women's camp. By that time, the researchers write, Anne Frank "was clearly already gravely ill," and Margot "was in an even worse condition than her sister."

Other inmates, including Auguste van Pels, who had hidden with the Franks, reported similar observations of the girls' health before they were transferred to Raghun, another slave-labor camp, on Feb. 7, 1945.
"In fact, this is where their trail runs cold," the researchers write.

Based on those eyewitness accounts and because Anne and Margot were already frail when they arrived at Bergen-Belsen, "it is unlikely that they survived until the end of March. In view of this, the date of their death is more likely to be sometime in February."
The earlier date lays to rest the notion that Anne and her sister were only days from being rescued when they died, researcher Erika Prins told the Guardian.
"When you say they died at the end of March, it gives you a feeling that they died just before liberation," Prins said. "Well, that's not true anymore."

WASHINGTON — Republican Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker sketched the outlines Friday of what will no doubt be the theme of his presumptive campaign for the presidency in 2016: sending money and power back to the states from the federal government.

Before an audience of policy wonks and reporters, Walker delivered a similar message in a well-received speech in Iowa last week. This time he ramped up his attacks on President Obama, who he accused of wanting mainly to improve the economy in Washington, whose region includes six of the top 10 richest counties in the United States.

"To me, that suggests there's a disconnect between those who want to grow government in Washington and the rest of us who want to grow the economy out with real people in cities and towns and villages all across this great country," Walker said. "And so that's where 'our American revival' that we've talked about is really about transferring that power from Washington back to the people."
Walker announced earlier this week that he has set up a federal committee named Our American Revival to raise money as he explores a presidential bid.

On Friday, Walker called for a tougher foreign policy than Obama's, a better balance between the economy and environmental concerns and fiscal policy. It's a "false choice," he said, to believe that taxes must be raised or government services slashed. Instead he said government leaders need to deliver services more efficiently.
In Wisconsin, Walker said, he has balanced the budget each year and cut taxes while improving education.
"We have made the tough decisions and our state is that much better off because of it," he said.

Walker touted his roll back of bargaining rights for public worker unions in Wisconsin, which led to a labor-inspired 2012 recall effort that he fought off. He said taking people receiving government assistance and putting them into employment readiness programs has helped transform the assistance program from a "hammock" into a back-to-work program.

Despite all the Washington-bashing, Walker did wax romantic about the city itself as he recounted flying in Thursday and being awed by the "beautiful" sites on the ground below — the National Cathedral, the Kennedy Center, the Washington Monument and the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials on the National Mall.

"It's just, there's something wonderful about coming in fresh to our nation's capital, and over the years it's never, I've never, lost that — looking at those great monuments and thinking about the great leaders of our time in this country," he said.

But he quickly switched gears, slamming the actions of politicians and bureaucrats in the capital and hailing the experience of returning to Wisconsin and outside the "68 square miles surrounded by reality."

Walker did not take questions from the about 40 attendees at the American Action Forum. Aides whisked him down a hall to a waiting elevator as reporters ran behind, asking for his comment on former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney's decision not to seek the 2016 GOP nomination for president.
"We'll put out a statement," Walker offered as the elevator doors closed.
